channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Battle for Bakhmut, in Photos
item.description: Times photographers have been documenting Ukraine’s defense of the Eastern city since May 2022.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers riding on an armored vehicle in Bakhmut in November.

item.title: Rare Assault Inside Russia Stretches Into Second Day
item.description: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it had pushed pro-Ukrainian fighters back across the border, but the group that claimed responsibility for the incursion said its attacks were continuing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Overlooking the St. Michael’s Church in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Turkey’s Next President Will Win an Economy in Peril
item.description: A surge in government spending before the election this month and pressure on the country’s currency could hit the economy in coming months, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A currency exchange office in Istanbul this month. Inflation has cut deeply into Turkish households’ ability to pay their bills, and the country faces a looming crisis.

item.title: How Women Are Giving Birth Amid Chaos in Sudan
item.description: War in the northeast African nation has forced pregnant women to drive “through hell” to reach the dwindling number of hospitals and clinics, or turn to overworked midwives to give birth at home.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Abdi Latif Dahir

item.title: With Pardon of Roman Protasevich, Belarus Fuels a Tale of Betrayal
item.description: Roman Protasevich became a symbol of the struggle for democracy when Belarus forced down a plane and arrested him. Now it has pardoned him, and former allies say he has turned on them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Protesters in Warsaw in 2021 with images of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, left, the activist Roman Protasevich, center, and Sofia Sapega, his former girlfriend, who is still imprisoned.

item.title: 4 Everest Ascents in 10 Days: Sherpas Battle for a Climbing Record
item.description: The friendly but grueling competition mixes monetary rewards with abundant dangers for a pair of veteran mountain guides.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kami Rita Sherpa with his son, Lakpa Tenzing, at their home in Kathmandu, Nepal, last year. Kami Rita Sherpa reached the summit of Mount Everest for a record-breaking 28th time on Tuesday.

item.title: Iran Dismisses Ali Shamkhani, Top National Security Official
item.description: Ali Shamkhani was one of the most powerful men in Iran, but it was not enough to insulate him after a close associate was accused of selling information to Britain.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Ali Shamkhani in 2018. On Monday, he was ousted from his role as Iran’s top national security official.

item.title: Russia Claims Bakhmut, but Some See a Pyrrhic Victory
item.description: A top Ukrainian official essentially acknowledged that the devastated city had been lost. Thousands of Ukrainian and Russian soldiers died there, but the cost for Moscow was especially steep, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers headed toward the front line near Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, in March. The battle had become one over roads by that time.

item.title: What Bakhmut Looks Like Now
item.description: Drone footage taken by The New York Times captured the scorched buildings, destroyed schools and cratered parks that now define the city in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora

item.title: Why Bakhmut? It’s a Question Older Than the Ukraine War.
item.description: The twists and turns of a war are rarely easy to predict. In Ukraine, they landed on a city in the east that few had ever heard of. And then the whole world watched for months.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Much of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, already seemed shelled to oblivion in December.

item.title: The Madeleine McCann Case: Here’s What We Know
item.description: A new search in Portugal has brought the case of the British girl, missing since 2007, back to the headlines.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A new search operation in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann was being conducted on Tuesday at the Arade Dam in the Algarve region of Portugal.

item.title: China and Russia, Targets of a Contentious G7 Summit, Draw Closer
item.description: Beijing and Moscow are holding visits this week as alarm grows in China that Western countries backing Ukraine are turning their attention to Asia.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Beijing’s harsh reaction to the G7 communiqué stems from fears of a U.S.-led coalition in Asia to contain China’s rise, analysts say.

item.title: Mexican Official, Alejandro Encinas, Victim of Pegasus Spyware Attack
item.description: While looking into abuses by the armed forces, the country’s top human rights official was targeted with Pegasus, the world’s most notorious spyware, The Times found.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Alejandro Encinas, Mexico’s under secretary for human rights, was targeted by spyware while investigating abuses by the nation’s military.

item.title: Fatal Fire at Guyana Dormitory Was ‘Maliciously Set,’ Official Says
item.description: Many of the 19 victims were schoolchildren. The fire service said it was still unclear who had set the building ablaze.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Investigators and government employees on Monday inspected the ruins of a girls’ dormitory that burned in Mahdia, Guyana.

item.title: U.S. Navy Steps Up Efforts to Curb Iran’s Ship Seizures in Strait of Hormuz
item.description: The United States is increasing patrols in the busy shipping lanes, where Iranian forces have taken two internationally flagged tankers in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An Iranian Revolutionary Guard speedboat watching an American warship in the Strait of Hormuz last week.

item.title: Who Are the Soldiers Behind the Free Russia Legion?
item.description: The unit has taken responsibility for a rare assault in Russian territory, and a member says it is just the beginning.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian soldiers with the Free Russian Legion training in February in the Kyiv region in preparation to deploy to the front lines.

item.title: Russian Judge Agrees to Extend Evan Gershkovich’s Detention for Three Months
item.description: The Wall Street Journal reporter has been held at the notoriously harsh Lefortovo jail since his arrest on March 29 during a reporting trip to the central Russian city of Yekaterinburg.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who was arrested on unsupported accusations of espionage in March, at a hearing in Moscow in April.

item.title: Australia Reckons With Stan Grant’s Exit from ABC Over Racist Abuse
item.description: Stan Grant, an Indigenous journalist, was attacked on social media after talking during coronation coverage about the brutality of colonialism.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, via Associated Press

item.title: Prince Harry Loses Bid to Pay for Police Protection in UK
item.description: The decision in Britain, where Harry lost police protection after stepping back from royal duties, comes amid heightened scrutiny of his security after an encounter with paparazzi in New York.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the High Court in London in March. He lost his automatic police protection when he pulled back from his duties as a member of the royal family.

item.title: Ron DeSantis’s Reality
item.description: The challenges that Gov. Ron DeSantis faces in any presidential run go beyond Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida speaks to New Hampshire state legislators at the Bedford Village Inn in Bedford, N.H.

item.title: An African Country Faces Challenges to Protect Girls From HPV
item.description: Almost all cervical cancer deaths now occur in developing countries. Tanzania is trying to inoculate girls against the virus that causes the disease — nearly 20 years after rich countries began offering the shot.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If she could be protected, it would be good,” said Pili Abdallah, left, of her daughter, Asia Shomari. Ms. Shomari had avoided health workers who came to her school in Dar es Salaam to administer HPV vaccines.

item.title: U.S. Shift to Support F-16s for Ukraine Began A Month Ago
item.description: The U.S. defense chief first asked Biden officials to support the plan after meeting with European allies. He made his pitch to President Biden last week.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: The U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III, and his Ukrainian counterpart, Oleksii Reznikov, at a meeting of what is known as the Ukraine Contact Group at Ramstein Air Base in Germany last month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Bakhmut is obliterated.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Drone footage showing the devastation across Bakhmut.

item.title: Madeleine McCann Disappearance: Portugal Searches for Missing Girl
item.description: The case of 3-year-old Madeleine McCann, who disappeared while vacationing with her family in Portugal, has drawn international attention for years.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Portuguese authorities gather near a dam in the southern region of Algarve on Monday before a new search connected to the disappearance of a 3-year-old in 2007.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bakhmut in Ruins
item.description: Plus, China bans some U.S. chips.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Sinn Fein Surges in Local Elections, Highlighting Northern Ireland’s Divide
item.description: As the party climbs, its rivals, the Democratic Unionists, are stalled, which means any compromise that could revive its power-sharing national government may remain elusive.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Social Democratic and Labour Party (Northern Ireland)
item.media:description: Michelle O’Neill is the head of Sinn Fein, which has made gains in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: Alert Level Is Raised in Central Mexico as Volcano Spews Smoke and Ash
item.description: Officials were preparing evacuation routes and shelters around the volcano, Popocatépetl, and some schools and parks were closed to minimize exposure to falling ash.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: Biden Sees Coming ‘Thaw’ With China, Even as He Rallies Allies Against Beijing
item.description: During the Group of 7 meeting that just wrapped up, President Biden forged a consensus approach toward China despite tensions between the major powers over their approach.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden has often said he does not desire to start a new Cold War with China.

item.title: Erdogan Is Endorsed by Sinan Ogan
item.description: The support of Sinan Ogan gives the Turkish president a boost as he takes on the opposition leader Kemal Kilicdaroglu.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster showing Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Istanbul, this month.

item.title: Fighting Reported in Russia’s Belgorod Region, Near the Border With Ukraine
item.description: The local governor blamed a Ukrainian sabotage group, while Kyiv’s military intelligence agency said that “opposition-minded citizens of Russia” were responsible.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Riley Mellen

item.title: E.U. Asks Greece to Investigate Video of Migrants Left at Sea
item.description: Citing a report by The Times, a top E.U. official said the Greek authorities had been urged to investigate after footage showed the Greek Coast Guard leaving asylum seekers at sea.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A still from a video showing a Greek Coast Guard vessel and migrants. A Times investigation verified and corroborated the footage.

item.title: Deal Is Reached to Keep Colorado River From Going Dry, for Now
item.description: The agreement on cuts, aided by a wet winter and $1.2 billion in federal payments, expires at the end of 2026.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Matthew Reamer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lake Mead, the largest reservoir in the country, is formed on the Colorado River at the Hoover Dam. The reservoir’s water level has significantly dropped, along with the river.

item.title: Belarus Said to Pardon Roman Protasevich, Activist Who Was Hauled Off a Ryanair Flight
item.description: Roman Protasevich had been sentenced to eight years in prison. The details of his 2021 arrest drew international attention.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The activist Roman Protasevich, center, at a news briefing organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Minsk, Belarus, in 2021.

item.title: Supreme Court Criticism
item.description: Democrats used to criticize the Supreme Court respectfully. Increasingly, they see the court as irredeemable.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court Building in April.

item.title: Andrew Tate Finds Romania Less Lawless Than He Hoped
item.description: The online influencer, popular with young men, is facing charges of human trafficking and rape, after seeking out a place where “corruption is accessible to everybody.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Andrew Tate, left, and his younger brother, Tristan, outside court in Bucharest in February. Mr. Tate has said he liked “living in a society where my money, my influence and my power” meant that he was not beholden to laws.

item.title: The Sound of France’s Pension Fury? The Saucepan.
item.description: Protesters have been harassing the French government in clanky demonstrations that have gone viral in a country with no shortage of kitchenware.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Protesters across France have taken to the streets with pots, pans, lids and spoons to make known their frustration over President Emmanuel Macron’s pension changes.

item.title: Zelensky wraps up another fruitful trip and Russia claims a big win in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Soldiers during a night operation near Bakhmut on Tuesday.

item.title: Fire Guts Manila’s Historic Post Office Building
item.description: Built in 1926, the structure is one of the Philippine capital’s most recognizable landmarks. The cause of the fire was unclear on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s assertions of victory in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing rockets near Bakhmut last week.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The G7 Wraps
item.description: Also, Russia claims that it captured Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky during a speech at the G7.

item.title: As Russia Claims Victory in Bakhmut, Ukraine Sees Opportunity Amid Ruins
item.description: Military analysts say that if Moscow continues to send reinforcements to defend the city, that could weaken Russian forces’ ability to hold off a broader counteroffensive that Ukraine has been planning.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The 80th Air Assault Brigade of Ukraine’s armed forces firing a barrage of rockets in the direction of Bakhmut during a night operation on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Announces More Aid for Ukraine as G7 Powers Meet in Japan
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden with President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Hiroshima, Japan, on Sunday.

item.title: Greece Elections: New Democracy on Track to Win Most Votes
item.description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis’s New Democracy party did not win enough votes to form a one-party government. But he appeared to rule out talks to form a coalition, setting the stage for a second vote in weeks.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Supporters of the governing New Democracy party in Athens after the first exit polls came in on Sunday.

item.title: Through Ukraine, Tech Start-Ups Make Their Move Into the U.S. Defense Industry
item.description: Small, fast-moving U.S. tech firms are using the war in Ukraine to demonstrate a new generation of military systems but face the challenge of selling them to a risk-averse Defense Department.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display showing Altius drones, made by Anduril Industries, at a military convention in National Harbor, Md., last month. New advances in autopilot technology helped inspire a flood of American start-ups.

item.title: Zelensky Says Images of a Ruined Hiroshima Remind Him of Bakhmut
item.description: While it “wouldn’t be fair” to compare Hiroshima to what is happening in his country, Ukraine’s president said the city’s atomic bomb museum offered grim echoes of fresh devastation.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Japan’s Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, right, and Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park on Sunday.

item.title: The Evidence for Therapy
item.description: Does talk therapy work? It’s complicated.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez

item.title: Sudan’s Warring Sides Agree to Weeklong Ceasefire
item.description: The truce is the first to be signed by both sides. It followed weeks of talks in Saudi Arabia between representatives of the two rival generals vying for power in the northeast African nation.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Saudi officials looked on as representatives of the Sudanese Army and the rival paramilitary Rapid Support Forces signed an agreement in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on Saturday for a cease-fire.

item.title: Why Does Ukraine Want F-16s?
item.description: Ukraine’s sizable contingent of fighter jets come with a few problems. President Volodymyr Zelensky said F-16s would “greatly enhance our army in the sky.”
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Inside the Barbecue City That Is China’s Hottest Tourist Destination
item.description: Zibo has become a social media star for its distinctive barbecue style. Now the city is overrun with visitors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local BBQ delicacies at a street market in the neighborhood of Badajiao, a street market now turned into a super popular tourist destination in Zibo.

item.title: The U.S. Needs Minerals for Electric Cars. Everyone Else Wants Them Too.
item.description: The United States is entering an array of agreements to secure the critical minerals necessary for the energy transition, but it’s not clear which of the arrangements can succeed.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chaerhan Salt Lake in Golmud, China, where brine is processed to extract lithium and other minerals.

item.title: What Number Comes Next? The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences Knows.
item.description: The “mathematical equivalent to the FBI’s voluminous fingerprint files” turns 50 this year, with 362,765 entries (and counting).
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:description: The Fibonacci sequence, in which every term (starting with the 3rd term) is the sum of the two preceding numbers, is one of the more familiar sequences in the On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, which first appeared as a handbook in 1973.

item.title: Fleeing Afghanistan, U.S. Allies Risk Journey Through Darién Gap
item.description: For thousands of Afghans, the American withdrawal from Kabul was just the beginning of a long, dangerous search for safety.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: As Greece Votes, Leader Says Blocking Migrants Built ‘Good Will’ With Europe
item.description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has taken a tough line on migrants as he turns around the country’s economy. It’s a trade-off that voters and the European Union seem more than willing to abide.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece, leader of the New Democracy party, at a rally in Athens on Friday.

item.title: Rahm Emanuel Pushes Japan on Gay Rights
item.description: The U.S. ambassador has enthusiastically embraced his host country. But critics say he has overstepped diplomatic bounds with his advocacy on equality.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: President Biden being greeted by Rahm Emanuel, the U.S. ambassador to Japan, upon his arrival for the Group of 7 summit on Thursday.

item.title: Russia’s Latest Sanctions on U.S. Officials Turn to Trump Enemies
item.description: Among the 500 people singled out for travel and financial restrictions were Americans seen as adversaries by former President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, on Capitol Hill last year.

item.title: 12 Dead in El Salvador Soccer Stadium Stampede
item.description: It was not immediately clear what prompted the rush at Cuscatlán Stadium in the capital. President Nayib Bukele vowed to conduct a thorough investigation.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: The scene after a deadly stampede at a soccer match on Saturday at Cuscatlán Stadium in San Salvador, El Salvador.

item.title: What’s De-risking and How Does It Compare to Decoupling
item.description: The newly fashionable term, reflecting an evolution in the discussion over dealing with a rising, assertive China, has a vexing history in financial policy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, with President Emmanuel Macron of France with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in April. She was crucial to bringing the term ‘de-risking,’ in the context of China, to wider awareness.

item.title: Typhoon Mawar Could Hit Guam With Force of Category 5 Storm
item.description: Forecasters said the storm was on track to hit the U.S. Pacific territory on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser, Judson Jones and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Rick Cruz/The Pacific Daily, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Residents in Guam preparing on Monday for the arrival of Typhoon Mawar. The governor of the Pacific island warned that it could take a direct hit from the storm.
